com.linkedin.parseq
Interface Context

All Known Implementing Classes:
ContextImpl
public interface Context

A context provides an API to Tasks for the purpose of scheduling other tasks. Each task gets its own context, but contexts are hierarchical such that any state changes made from this context are visible to other contexts in the hierarchy.

If a task finished while it still has pending timers or tasks, those timers and tasks will be cancelled - they are guaranteed not to execute.

Author:
Chris Pettitt (cpettitt@linkedin.com)

Method Summary
 After after(Promise<?>... promises)
          Provides a mechanism of ordering the execution of some child tasks after the resolution of the given promises (which may also be tasks).

 void run(Task<?>... tasks)
          Runs one or more tasks in parallel.
 

Method Detail

createTimer

Cancellable createTimer(long time,
                        java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit,
                        Task<?> task)
Creates a timer that will invoke the given task if the calling task has not yet finished.

Parameters:
time - the time for the timeout
unit - the unit of the time
task - the task to run if the timeout expires
Returns:
a handle that can be used to explicitly cancel the timer

run

void run(Task<?>... tasks)
Runs one or more tasks in parallel.

Parameters:
tasks - the tasks to run

after

After after(Promise<?>... promises)
Provides a mechanism of ordering the execution of some child tasks after the resolution of the given promises (which may also be tasks).

Parameters:
promises - the promises that must be resolved before executing tasks from After
Returns:
a handle that can be used to schedule tasks that will be executed after the given promises are resolved.
